Introduction

Impulse control disorders are characterized by the inability to self-regulate emotions and urges, resulting in behaviors that violate the rights of others and/or conflict with societal norms.  These disorders include intermittent explosive disorder, kleptomania, and pyromania.

Intermittent explosive disorder

Clinical presentation



Intermittent explosive disorder is characterized by recurrent aggressive impulses toward animals, other people, or property that may or may not result in damage or physical injury.  Behaviors can include verbal arguments, threats to harm others, shoving/pushing, punching or breaking objects, road rage, or, at the most extreme, killing an animal or person.



The aggressive impulse occurs with minimal provocation and is typically preceded by rising tension that escalates rapidly to a state of rage in which there is no thought about the consequences of behavior.  Most episodes last less than 30 minutes and can be followed by a sense of relief, remorse, or embarrassment.

Diagnosis



For a diagnosis of intermittent explosive disorder, the following criteria must be met:



  • The patient displays recurrent behavioral outbursts representing a failure to control aggressive impulses, as manifested by either of the following:

    • Verbal aggression (eg, temper tantrums, fights) or physical aggression toward property, animals, or other individuals, occurring twice weekly, on average, for a period of 3 months.  The physical aggression does not result in damage or destruction of property and does not result in physical injury to animals or other individuals.
    • Three behavioral outbursts involving damage or destruction of property and/or physical assault involving physical injury against animals or other individuals occurring within a 12-month period.
  • The magnitude of aggressiveness expressed during the recurrent outbursts is grossly out of proportion to the provocation or to any precipitating psychosocial stressors.
  • The recurrent aggressive outbursts are not premeditated (they are impulsive and/or anger-based) and are not committed to achieve some tangible objective (eg, money, power, intimidation).
  • The recurrent aggressive outbursts cause marked distress in the individual, impairment in occupational/interpersonal functioning, or financial/legal consequences.
  • The patient is age â‰¥6 (or equivalent developmental level).
  • The recurrent aggressive outbursts are not better explained by another mental disorder and are not attributable to another medical condition (eg, head trauma) or to the physiological effects of a substance.

Management



Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) may be effective in reducing aggressive behaviors.



Screening and safety planning are indicated due to an increased risk for suicidal behavior.  In addition, screening for and treating cooccurring disorders (posttraumatic stress disorder, personality disorders, substance use disorders) are indicated.

Prognosis



Intermittent explosive disorder typically follows a persistent course that can be lifelong.

Kleptomania

Clinical presentation



The impulses to steal objects are preceded by feelings of anxiety or tension and followed by pleasure and/or relief.  Attempts are usually made to resist the impulse to steal (although the attempt is unsuccessful), and patients often feel guilty about their behaviors.  Patients often give away or discard the stolen objects, and others may hoard or try to secretly return them.



The stolen objects are typically of low monetary value and affordable for the patient to buy.



Shoplifting (theft) is much more common than kleptomania and is done for personal gain.

Diagnosis



For a diagnosis of kleptomania, the following criteria must be met:



  • The patient experiences recurrent failure to resist impulses to steal objects that are not needed for personal use or for their monetary value.
  • The patient experiences an increasing sense of tension immediately before committing the theft.
  • The patient experiences pleasure, gratification, or relief at the time of committing the theft.
  • The stealing is not committed to express anger or vengeance and is not in response to a delusion or a hallucination.
  • The stealing is not better explained by conduct disorder, a manic episode, or antisocial personality disorder.

Management



SSRIs and CBT may be effective in reducing impulsive behaviors.  Screening and safety planning are indicated due to an increased risk for suicidal behavior.  Screening for and treating cooccurring disorders (eg, depressive disorders, bulimia nervosa) is also indicated.

Prognosis



The course of kleptomania is often persistent (chronic) and includes recurrent episodes with periods of remission.

Pyromania

Clinical presentation



Fire setting in pyromania is deliberate, preceded by a sense of tension or arousal, and followed by a sense of relief or pleasure.  Fire watching is enjoyable, and patients may set off false alarms to witness the emergency response.  Patients typically have a fascination with objects related to fires, including lighters, matches, fire trucks/equipment, and fire stations; some patients become firefighters.



Individuals may intentionally set fires for reasons other than pyromania, including for revenge, to make a political statement, or as childhood experimentation (eg, playing with matches).

Diagnosis



For a diagnosis of pyromania, the following criteria must be met:



  • Deliberate and purposeful fire setting on >1 occasion
  • Tension or affective arousal before the act
  • Fascination with, interest in, curiosity about, or attraction to fire and its situational contexts (eg, uses, consequences)
  • Pleasure, gratification, or relief when setting fires or when witnessing or participating in their aftermath
  • Fire setting not done for monetary gain, as an expression of sociopolitical ideology, to conceal criminal activity, to express anger or vengeance, to improve one's living circumstances, in response to a delusion or hallucination, or as a result of impaired judgment (eg, intoxication with a substance)
  • Fire setting not better explained by conduct disorder, a manic episode, or antisocial personality disorder

Management



CBT may be effective in reducing impulsive fire setting and improving coping skills.  Screening and safety planning are indicated due to an increased risk for suicidal behavior.  In addition, patients require screening for and treating cooccurring disorders (eg, substance use disorders).

Prognosis



Pyromania often follows a chronic course, with waxing and waning symptoms.

Summary



Impulse control disorders, including intermittent explosive disorder, kleptomania, and pyromania, involve an inability to self-regulate emotions and urges, resulting in behaviors that violate the rights of others and/or conflict with societal norms.  Treatment can include selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and cognitive-behavioral therapy.
